topic.title: Few ZeroNet Peers coming from Un-Free Countries
topic.body: I'm noticing on the ZeroNet STATS page that by far the most peers that are currently on line are in "free" countries, like the US and Western Europe.  There are only a tiny number from un-free places, like China and the Middle East.  What does that say about the reasons people are using ZeroNet and its effectiveness for people who really need to use it to access news outside their countries?  The recent post from the boarding school kid seems to indicate that TOR nodes are being blocked by any school (or by implication, country) that cares to do so.  If this is the case, then wouldn't it be impossible for ZeroNet users to form their own little local networks inside un-free countries, other than by hand-carrying data files to each other?  Or would those users just communicate with each other over their local, sectioned-off part of the clearnet, without going through TOR nodes?  If someone is reading this post from one of those countries (or boarding schools), please (if you feel it's safe to do so) let us know how you are reading it.

topic.title: Skywire
topic.body:
I just came across information about Skywire, which is a decentralized network that uses skycoin as an incentive to use it.  I would love for this thing to become operational.  However, the skycoin  "miners" (not really miners, just used to process transactions) are sold by the Skywire organization for $2000 US each.  The software won't run on any other hardware (I think).   And the actual value of the hardware (as I figure it) is only about $500.  Also, the technical details of how the network will be set up are not well thought out.  The network starts out over the internet and then at some point transitions to a wifi peer-to-peer mesh network.  The problem is that wifi just does not have anything like the range needed to successfully transition off the internet.  I'm guessing that would initially require a range of something like 10 km.  So, this sounds to me like it might be a pyramid scheme dreamed up by a group of marketers.  Here are some links:

https://www.coinbureau.com/review/skycoin/
https://barbucrypto.com/2019/03/skywire-mainnet-skycoin-heralds-public-release/
https://www.skycoin.net/

Does anyone have any thoughts?

topic.title: How can you buy bitcoin without identifying yourself?
topic.body: I know bitcoin is not inherently anonymous, but if you never associate any personal information with any of your transactions, it can be made anonymous--at least, until you make a mistake.  The biggest problem is conveniently converting fiat currency into bitcoin in the first place.  I am aware that you can do this anonymously with bitquick.co and paxful.com.  However, the usefulness of bitquick.co is ending, because most banks no longer allow deposits into customers' accounts without ID.  It's also not all that convenient.  You have to use a burner phone in the transaction, go to a bank, photograph and email a bank receipt, etc.  I'm currently investigating paxful, but it seems to have problems too.  Already, it may be blocking my account, because I am connecting through TOR.  Does anyone know a secure and CONVENIENT way of buying bitcoin without revealing your identity?

topic.title: The Days of having an Anonymous Email Account may be Ending
topic.body: I noticed you can no longer sign up for protonmail or tutanota over TOR.  Protonmail still works over TOR, if you already have an account.  Someone said you can still get a  tutanota account, even though it acts like you can't.   You just wait 48 hours after creating the account to log in.  I haven't confirmed this.  My current tutanota account told me last week that my password was wrong, even though I know it was right.  If the 48-hour wait to log onto tutnatota doesn't work, it leaves us with throwawaymail.com as one of the few anonymous email providers left.  Yandex is another that I've used recently.  Does anyone know of any email providers that work over TOR and also provide some privacy from snooping?

topic.title: The Pros and Cons of Cryptocurrencies
topic.body:
Pros: 
-Excellent medium of exchange
-Easy to store
-Easy to carry across any national border
-Hard to steal, if you take the proper precautions
-Infinitely divisible

Cons:
-Very poor store of value, because anyone can create their own cryptocurrency with the same algorithm as any other.  So, cryptocurrencies are fungible, and in infinite supply.
-Can be legislated out of existence (thanks mostly to the stupidity of the masses).  [India is about to start imprisoning people for using cryptocurrencies.](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/policy/indian-panel-recommends-ban-on-cryptocurrency/articleshow/70331293.cms)
-If you lose your wallet password, your cryptocurrency is gone forever.
-Easily stolen, if you use a crypto exchange

topic.title: Installing the python 3 version of ZeroNet onto Linux Mint
topic.body:
Following the instruction [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/16Go5kc2U9Ff4jeaY8kYiDEgpMYdgyboPY/?Topic:2_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS/How+to+Install+and+run+Zeronet+on+a+Raspberry+Pi+or+any+Linux+computer) nearly worked on Linux Mint 17. However, I could not find a python BTL module. Is it part of some other module? Here is what I have so far:

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:jonathonf/python-3.6
sudo apt update
sudo apt-get install python3.6
wget https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py
sudo python3.6 get-pip.py
sudo -H python3.6 -m pip install --upgrade pip
sudo -H python3.6 -m pip install cffi --upgrade
sudo -H python3.6 -m pip install gevent --upgrade
sudo -H python3.6 -m pip install bencode --upgrade
sudo -H python3.6 -m pip install merkletools --upgrade
sudo -H python3.6 -m pip install coincurve --upgrade
sudo -H python3.6 -m pip install base58 --upgrade
sudo -H python3.6 -m pip install msgpack-python --upgrade

When I try to run ZeroNet with:
python3.6 /home/mint/ZeroNet-py3/zeronet.py --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150 --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151

It gives the following error:

    Starting ZeroNet...
    [05:40:09] - Libsecpk256k1 loaded
    [05:40:09] - Unhandled exception: No module named 'BTL'
    Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/home/mint/ZeroNet-py3/zeronet.py", line 18, in main
    import main
    File "/home/mint/ZeroNet-py3/src/main.py", line 63, in <module>

    PluginManager.plugin_manager.loadPlugins()
    File "/home/mint/ZeroNet-py3/src/Plugin/PluginManager.py", line 67, in loadPlugins
    func()
    File "/home/mint/ZeroNet-py3/plugins/AnnounceZero/AnnounceZeroPlugin.py", line 18, in importHostClasses
    from Site.SiteAnnouncer import AnnounceError
    File "/home/mint/ZeroNet-py3/src/Site/SiteAnnouncer.py", line 10, in <module>

    import bencode
    File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/bencode/init.py", line 13, in <module>

    from BTL import BTFailure
    ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'BTL'

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This did not appear to do anything:
apt-get install python-cffi python-gevent python-msgpack

topic.title: US State Department, Stop Violating our Virgins.
topic.body:
An acquaintance of mine who is a virgin and works for the US State Department is required to get a pap smear as part of a physical before she goes overseas for work assignments.  Her doctor was appalled that this medically unnecessary and painful procedure was required, even though it is of no benefit and is actually detrimental to the health of virgins.  So, the doctor wrote a letter saying this, which this woman presented to the State Department people who were requiring the pap smear.  Their response was to ignore the doctor's letter and continue to require the woman to get the pap smear.  Obviously, the US government has no concern for the health of their female workers.  Just another example of how governments pretend to be concerned about people but actually could not care less about them.

Write about that, reporters lurking on ZeroNet!

topic.title: ZeroNet Encryption Questions
topic.body:
I'm still confused by discussions such as these:

http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1552634420_1e2mHauMGG8GgSDvaaPrNanxvaxwpGQRV
http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1562744772_1G5aYYLCYtwKYfnnvLUTNVDC5kmy8RP7D7

My understanding is that if I am using the TOR browser and ZeroHello shows that TOR Always mode is active, all ZeroNet traffic to and from my computer is encrypted with TLSv1.2.  Is this true, or is it just encrypted between the TOR entry node and the TOR exit node, leaving ZeroNet traffic unencrypted at my ISP's gateway?

If the former is true and all ZeroNet traffic is encrypted to and from my computer, then why are people saying to use a VPN also?  Is it due to the fact that governments are known to be able to get around TLS encryption?

Why does ZeroNet not do its own encryption of all traffic on ZeroNet (all traffic between all peers)?  Is it because anyone who downloads ZeroNet has access to the keys necessary to decrypt the traffic, so for instance, my ISP could just get those keys and decrypt my data to and from other ZeroNet peers?

topic.title: I2P Install not working.
topic.body:
I tried to install I2P on my Linux Mint 17 computer.  I'm seeing I2P network traffic on my computer, but whenever I try to go to any external  I2P website, my browser (both TOR browser and Firefox) say they can't see the website.  None of the information on the internet about installing I2P seems to fix the problem.

I installed I2p on Linux Mint 17 using:

   sudo apt-add-repository ppa:i2p-maintainers/i2p
   sudo apt-get update
   sudo apt-get install i2p

In the Connection Settings panel of the TOR browser and Firefox, I checked the ‘Manual proxy configuration’ box.  I entered these settings HTTP Proxy: 127.0.0.1, Port: 4444, SSL Proxy: 127.0.0.1, Port: 4444. I typed ‘localhost, 127.0.0.1 into the ‘No Proxy for’ box.  I set SOCKS Host: 127.0.0.1  Port: 9150, and I also tried SOCKS Host: 127.0.0.1  Port: 0.

I tried FoxyProxy, but you have to have a subscription to use it, and I'm not willing to do that.

Any ideas about what I'm doing wrong?

topic.title: Heaven and Hell and ZeroNet
topic.body:
A tough, brawny samurai once approached a Zen master who was deep in meditation.

Impatient and discourteous, the samurai demanded in his husky voice so accustomed to forceful yelling, “Tell me the nature of heaven and hell.”

The Zen master opened his eyes, looked the samurai in the face, and replied with a certain scorn, “Why should I answer to a shabby, disgusting, despondent slob like you? A worm like you, do you think I should tell you anything? I can’t stand you. Get out of my sight. I have no time for silly questions.”

The samurai could not bear these insults. Consumed by rage, he drew his sword and raised it to sever the master’s head at once.

Looking straight into the samurai’s eyes, the Zen master tenderly declared, “That’s hell.”

The samurai froze. He immediately understood that anger had him in its grip. His mind had just created his own hell—one filled with resentment, hatred, self-defense, and fury. He realized that he was so deep in his torment that he was ready to kill somebody.

The samurai’s eyes filled with tears. Setting his sword aside, he put his palms together and obsequiously bowed in gratitude for this insight.

The Zen master gently acknowledged with a delicate smile, “And that’s heaven.”


Do you want ZeroNet to be a heaven or a hell?  Behave accordingly.

topic.title: MayVaneDay
topic.body:
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MeeJWbbQHArbqD6UUHSjh9EVycvnTUBFa/

I happened to come across this nice, early-1990's-style zite with a lot of interesting stuff on it.  I couldn't find it on 0List or ZeroSites.  I wanted to send the author an email letting him know how much I enjoyed his website, but he gives no contact information, except for his GPG key and this quote, "Othernet. Beyond Facebook, beyond social media. Where will you and I talk? Where will you and I meet, beyond the grave, in the place where there is no darkness?" Then he gives a list of Tilde servers.  What is a Tilde server?   Is he looking for the most esoteric method of communication possible?  I couldn't find anything mentioning him on the clearnet, except for a Github location.  His website is mirrored on Dat, I2p, and TOR, and it is still active.  He also has 5 downloadable science fiction books.  I started reading the first, and it wasn't bad.

This is the kind of zite we need more of on ZeroNet.

topic.title: ZeroTalk Tech
topic.body: Some ZeroNet users have told me that few people know about [ZeroTalk Tech](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EfLnw7GDXbZfJmGNoXGQ4XkuHGWkRZTMq/).  So, I thought maybe I should advertise occasionally.  ZeroTalk Tech is a clone of ZeroTalk where anyone can post about anything related to any type of technology, not just computer technology.  Lately, I've mostly been posting technology-related news articles.  Sometimes I talk about other things on my mind, like my recent discovery that the PirateBox program has been mothballed.  I also occasionally post especially well-written articles that I find around the internet about what it's like to work at a technical job, something I know about from personal experience.

topic.title: America has one of the world's worst coronavirus responses
topic.body:
https://theweek.com/articles/903353/america-worlds-worst-coronavirus-responses

Ignoring politics, in reading the above story, I had to agree with most of the important points that were made.  If nothing changes, and fast, the United States is about to suffer a huge death tole.  Various hospitals have already announced that they are at capacity, and this pandemic has just started!  Two days ago our local radio station broadcast a message from our local hospital saying, "If you are suffering from Covid-19-like symptoms, DON'T COME TO THE HOSPITAL!"  And, I am nowhere near California or New York.  I'm not even in a major city.

[This article](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/10/from-confidence-to-quarantine-how-coronavirus-swept-italy) says the mistake Italy made was ignoring people who were sick with covid-19-like symptoms.  My sister says she knows of two people who went to the hospital with covid-19-like symptoms, were tested, were told their illness was not the flu, and at that point, they were told to go home.  One occurred months ago.  Nothing was investigated further, no one was curious about what was making them sick.  I can imagine the doctor burping, farting, scratching his butt, and walking out of the exam room.  Our so-called medical "professionals" really are like the keystone cops of the world's medical professionals.

The worst part is that as I write this, I am watching a never-ending parade of traffic on the street outside my home.  I'm wondering where all these people going!  Why aren't they at home in isolation?!  I'm telling you that huge numbers of people are not taking this pandemic seriously.  They are going about their lives as usual, behaving exactly as they always have.  When 20% of them need hospitalization from covid-19, they will not get it!

topic.title: Doctors And Nurses Say More People Are Dying Of COVID-19 In The US Than We Know
topic.body:
https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/nidhiprakash/coronavirus-update-dead-covid19-doctors-hospitals

"Some medical professionals said that it isn’t just a lack of testing that’s leading to a probable under-counting of people who contracted COVID-19 and the deaths caused by COVID-19. They said there’s also a lag in county and state records reflecting the positive COVID-19 test results and deaths they’re seeing first hand. It’s not clear why that’s the case.

'We have confirmed at least 5 cases in our hospital, but official state reporting only lists one case in our entire county,' said one department head at a small hospital in Mississippi, referring to patients who had tested positive for COVID-19 but were not reflected in county numbers."

"Robert Jensen, CEO of Kenyon International, a private company that specializes in disaster response where there’s a significant death count, said that it’s not surprising that the official numbers have not caught up to what medical professionals are seeing on the front lines.

'Right now, everyone is just doing it ad-hoc. I don't think the documents have even caught up because I think those things take weeks, and I don’t think they’ll catch up for some time,' he said."

    'I wish we had quarantined them sooner because we would have made progress sooner. topic.title: Perhaps We are Forgetting the Point of ZeroNet?
topic.body:
I've been frequenting ZeroNet now for over a year, and I find my self looking more and more for entertaining and interesting content.  Maybe I have begun to lose sight of the point of ZeroNet.  I need to remind myself occasionally that ZeroNet was created by Nofish to provide a means of communication, should we reach a point where all other means have been taken from us.  The splintering of the Internet into government-controlled walled gardens has already begun in countries like Russia, China, and Iran.  In the United States and in many other countries that call themselves democracies, under the guise of preventing "fake news", laws are being passed and other controls are being put in place to prevent us from saying things governments don't like or are afraid of (while politicians are given free reign to continue telling the lies they've always told).  But this is happening slowly over a period of years.  Slow processes are less noticeable and harder to maintain vigilance against.  

I and others try to come up with interesting content to keep people aware that ZeroNet exists, so that it will be here when they need it.  ZeroNet is a place where everyone can, and should, create content.  If we just want to be consumers of content, we can do that within all the walled gardens that already exist.  We can watch cat videos all over the Internet.  ZeroNet should be a place where we can let each other know what is occurring in our respective countries and discuss what we think about it and means of keeping communication open.  This and other decentralized networks that are mostly beyond the control of governments and the identification of those on them should be places where we are discussing those topics.  But, lately I have been noticing the volume of conversation declining.  

For a while, I was seeing comments appearing on ZeroTalk every couple of minutes.  Now, that has slowed to hours.  Why is this happening?  Are we becoming complacent?  Are people simply becoming bored?  Are people migrating to ZeroNet zites with cat videos and ignoring forums that have substantial, free-speech-oriented content?  Are they leaving ZeroNet for other decentralized networks that are better?  I know some have left after being confronted with the same old abusive comments that they find in other forums all over the Internet.  The valuable content they were finding here wasn't sufficient to counterbalance the abuse.  They are probably gone for good.  What are your thoughts about why ZeroTalk volume is down?  What can we do to increase it?  Or, are there better Zites on ZeroNet than ZeroTalk where important free-speech and open-communication topics are being discussed?

I think I've been seeing the more abusive denizens of ZeroNet slowly losing interest and leaving.  So, perhaps ZeroNet is becoming a safer place for the more sensitive among us?  What do you think?

topic.title: Bypassing China's Great Firewall
topic.body:
I found the following information at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_censorship_in_China#Evasion.  Below is a direct quote from the Wikipedia page.  Hopefully someone will find it useful.

Using a VPN service:

Internet censorship in China is circumvented by determined parties by using proxy servers outside the firewall. Users may circumvent all of the censorship and monitoring of the Great Firewall if they have a working VPN or SSH connection method to a computer outside mainland China. However, disruptions of VPN services have been reported and the free or popular services especially are increasingly being blocked. To avoid deep packet inspection and continue providing services in China some VPN providers implemented server obfuscation.

Changing IP addresses:

Blogs hosted on services such as Blogger and Wordpress.com are frequently blocked. In response, some China-focused services explicitly offer to change a blog's IP address within 30 minutes if it is blocked by the authorities.
Using a mirror website

In 2002, Chinese citizens used the Google mirror elgooG after China blocked Google.

Modifying the network stack:

In July 2006, researchers at Cambridge University claimed to have defeated the firewall by ignoring the TCP reset packets.
Using Tor and DPI-resistant tools

Although many users use VPNs to circumvent the Great Firewall of China, many Internet connections are now subject to deep packet inspection, in which data packets are looked at in detail. Many VPNs have been blocked using this method. Blogger Grey One suggests users trying to disguise VPN usage forward their VPN traffic through port 443 because this port is also heavily used by web browsers for HTTPS connections. However, Grey points out this method is futile against advanced inspection. Obfsproxy and other pluggable transports do allow users to evade deep-packet inspection.

The Tor anonymity network was and is subject to partial blocking by China's Great Firewall. The Tor website is blocked when accessed over HTTP but it is reachable over HTTPS so it is possible for users to download the Tor Browser Bundle. The Tor project also maintains a list of website mirrors in case the main Tor website is blocked.

The Tor network maintains a public list of approximately 3000 entry relays; almost all of them are blocked. In addition to the public relays, Tor maintains bridges which are non-public relays. Their purpose is to help censored users reach the Tor network. The Great Firewall scrapes nearly all the bridge IPs distributed through bridges.torproject.org and email. According to Winter's research paper published in April 2012, this blocking technique can be circumvented by using packet fragmentation or the Tor obfsproxy bundle in combination with private obfsproxy bridges. Tor Obfs4 bridges still work in China as long as the IPs are discovered through social networks or self-published bridges.

Tor now primarily functions in China using meeks which works via front-end proxies hosted on Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) to obfuscate the information coming to and from the source and destination, it is a type of pluggable transport. Examples are Microsoft's Azure and Cloudflare.

Unintended methods:

It was common in the past to use Google's cache feature to view blocked websites. However, this feature of Google seems to be under some level of blocking, as access is now erratic and does not work for blocked websites. Currently, the block is mostly circumvented by using proxy servers outside the firewall and is not difficult to carry out for those determined to do so.

The mobile Opera Mini browser uses a proxy-based approach employing encryption and compression to speed up downloads. This has the side effect of allowing it to circumvent several approaches to Internet censorship. In 2009 this led the government of China to ban all but a special Chinese version of the browser.

Using an analogy to bypass keyword filters:

As the Great Firewall of China gets more sophisticated, users are getting increasingly creative in the ways they elude the censorship, such as by using analogies to discuss topics. Furthermore, users are becoming increasingly open in their mockery of them by actively using homophones to avoid censorship. Deleted sites have "been harmonized", indicating CPC general secretary Hu Jintao's Internet censorship lies under the larger idea of creating a "Socialist Harmonious Society". For example, censors are referred to as "river crabs", because in Chinese that phrase forms a homophone for "harmony".

Using steganography:

According to The Guardian editor Charles Arthur, Internet users in China have found more technical ways to get around the Great Firewall of China, including using Steganography, a practice of "embedding useful data in what looks like something irrelevant. The text of a document can be broken into its constituent bytes, which are added to the pixels of an innocent picture. The effect is barely visible on the picture, but the recipient can extract it with the right software".

Voices:

Rupert Murdoch famously proclaimed that advances in communications technology posed an "unambiguous threat to totalitarian regimes everywhere" and Ai Weiwei argued that the Chinese "leaders must understand it's not possible for them to control the Internet unless they shut it off".

However, Nathan Freitas, a fellow at the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard and technical adviser to the Tibet Action Institute, says "There’s a growing sense within China that widely used VPN services that were once considered untouchable are now being touched." In June 2015 Jaime Blasco, a security researcher at AlienVault in Silicon Valley, reported that hackers, possibly with the assistance of the Chinese government, had found ways to circumvent the most popular privacy tools on the Internet: virtual private networks, or VPNs, and Tor. This is done with the aid of a particularly serious vulnerability, known as JSONP, that 15 web services in China never patched. As long as the users are logged into one of China's top web services such as Baidu, Taobao, QQ, Sina, Sohu, and Ctrip the hackers can identify them and access their personal information, even if they are using Tor or a VPN. The vulnerability is not new; it was published in a Chinese security and web forum around 2013.

topic.title: Accomplished pharma prof thrown in psych hospital after questioning official COVID narrative
topic.body:
https://www.lifesitenews.com/news/accomplished-pharma-prof-thrown-in-psych-hospital-after-questioning-official-covid-narrative

"December 11, 2020 (LifeSiteNews) — Early on December 10, Jean-Bernard Fourtillan, a French retired university professor known for his strong opposition to COVID-19 vaccines such as those presently being distributed in the U.K., was taken from his temporary home in the south of France by a team of 'gendarmes' — French law enforcement officers under military command — and forcibly placed in solitary confinement at the psychiatric hospital of Uzès. His mobile phones were taken from him, and at the time of writing, he had not been allowed to communicate with the outside world. The order for his internment appears to have been issued by the local 'préfet,' the official representative of the French executive.

The systematic use of psychiatric hospitals in order to silence or punish political opponents became widespread under communism, having started shortly after the Bolshevik revolution in Russia in 1917. The method developed under Stalin and then expanded as opposition to the 'socialist paradise' came to be considered a sign of mental illness. Under the 1966 penal code of the USSR, repression of dissidents openly targeted those who 'spread false propaganda defaming the Soviet State and its social system.'"

The Health Ministry announced that use of the vaccine was 'suspended as a precaution' on the basis of advice from the national health regulator, the Paul Ehrlich Institute (PEI). According to the Health Ministry, the European Medicines Agency (EMA) will decide 'whether and how the new information will affect the authorization of the vaccine' pending an investigation.

'After new reports of thrombroses of the cerebral veins in connection with the vaccination in Germany and Europe, the PEI considers further investigations to be necessary,' the Health Ministry announced."

topic.title: Judges weigh banning Capitol riot suspects from the internet
topic.body:
https://newswest.org/judges-weigh-banning-capitol-riot-suspects-from-the-internet/

"Beverly Hills esthetician and eyelash stylist Gina Bisignano was so present on social media that the federal criminal complaint against her practically wrote itself.

The story of a 52-year-old salon owner who charted a dark path of disinformation to the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, where she allegedly grabbed a bullhorn and urged rioters to take up weapons, is backed by one social media post after another embedded in the Department of Justice filing.

There is Bisignano in her Louis Vuitton sweater, filmed in front of the Capitol talking about her business and hometown as the riot was getting underway. There she is again, addressing rioters with a rant about globalists, George Soros and stolen votes. And again, calling for weapons and gas masks moments before a rioter attacks an officer with what appears to be a baseball bat.

Now, Bisignano has gone silent online. She is not allowed on the internet. Not because social media platforms banned her, but because a federal judge did. If Bisignano goes online while awaiting trial, she risks being jailed.

Judges have long been reluctant to ban anyone from the internet, a restriction that essentially cuts a person off from much of modern society and has been reserved mostly for accused and convicted pedophiles. But as toxic disinformation becomes an increasingly dangerous threat, driving domestic terrorism and violence, the courts are facing vexing new questions around how often and under what circumstances those accused of taking part should be taken offline altogether.

'We are headed into uncharted waters,' said Nina Jankowicz, a fellow at the Wilson Center, a Washington think tank, where she studies disinformation. 'Given the threats we see continuing and the heightened alerts, it is clear things are not dissipating. … That is why judges are making these calls.'

In the case of Bisignano, the ban might have been an easy one for the judge to make. The defendant asked for it. Her lawyer saw it as one of the few bargaining chips the Capitol riot suspect from California had to stay out of jail for now.

'If it weren’t for social media, she wouldn’t even be a defendant,' said Bisignano’s attorney, Charles Peruto. 'She knows that is what got her jammed in the first place.'

Yet attorneys for others accused of taking part in the attack on the Capitol are aggressively fighting the restrictions, and judges are struggling with how far to take them."

I thought they only did things like this in China.

topic.title: "I Refused to Become an FBI Informant, and the Government Put Me on the No Fly List"
topic.body:
https://www.aclu.org/news/national-security/i-refused-to-become-an-fbi-informant-and-the-government-put-me-on-the-no-fly-list/

"My first interaction with the FBI was based on a lie.

In August 2018, I got a call asking me to go to City Hall to clear up a city permit violation, and gladly complied to resolve any issues. It turned out to be a ruse.

When I arrived, I was led into a conference room, where two FBI agents were waiting. I was immediately caught off guard, not having any idea why the FBI would want to talk to me. I’m a husband and father of two young kids, and I have always focused on building a good life with my family, both as a business owner and as an engineer in Michigan’s automotive industry. 

Although the FBI agents told me I could leave whenever I wanted, when the door closed and they started questioning me, it certainly didn’t feel that way. They told me they wanted my help in looking for people in my community who might want to harm this country. They thought I’d be useful to the FBI because of my language skills (in addition to English, I speak Arabic), my Lebanese heritage, and my engineering expertise. I felt unsettled because becoming an informant in my community would violate my personal ethics. Still, I maintained my calm, told the agents my primary obligation was to my family, and that I didn’t want to work for the FBI. But the pressure continued.

The FBI agents asked me about my political and religious beliefs, associations, and the years I spent living in Lebanon as a student. I answered all their questions truthfully. I was born in Chicago, and completed high school and three years of college in Lebanon before returning home to Michigan to finish my education. 

I repeatedly insisted I did not want to work for the FBI, but they kept increasing the pressure. I was shocked when the FBI agents accused me of affiliation with a terrorist group. I vehemently denied their false accusations, but it didn’t seem to matter. My anxiety level rose even more when the agents threatened my family and me. They said that if I didn’t agree to become an informant, my family would be investigated, my wife and I could be arrested, my children could be taken away, and my wife’s immigration status could be at risk. "

FBI agents who use thuggish tactics are thugs.

topic.title: India’s second wave of covid-19 feels nothing like its first
topic.body:
https://www.economist.com/diary/2021/04/30/indias-second-wave-of-covid-19-feels-nothing-like-its-first

"The official news outlets also bring the daily statistics: 386,000 new infections today, 208,000 dead counted since the pandemic began. Between the lines, it is possible to read the disclaimers too. If only 1.7m tests are being conducted per day, what can that 386,000 really mean? Is it that 0.0004% of the country has come down with the virus since yesterday, or that nearly 23% did? That would be 314m people, nearly the whole population of America. Obviously, the true number lies between those absurd extremes, but who knows where? The statistics about death tolls are more nakedly false. It is plain that thousands are dying every day, but who, where and exactly how many we cannot know, thanks to some petty deceptions but mostly sheer confusion."

"Which brings us to the fact that this time young people and even children are developing symptoms, including an erstwhile quarantine-playmate of our four-year-old. Younger adults are becoming severely ill, as they did not last year. Finally, those people who have had the disease twice, a plentiful category thanks to that “immune-escape” feature, say that the reinfection feels different. The fever comes quicker and they are more prone to developing pneumonia."

topic.title: What is Better than ZeroNet?
topic.body: I am hearing people complain that ZeroNet is dead and obsolete.  They point to various alternative distributed networks or distributed apps as being better and more modern.  But, when I look at the alternatives, I don't see anything better than ZeroNet.  Does anyone know of a distributed network that actually is better than ZeroNet?  Also, do we really care if ZeroNet is obsolete?  If it still works as well as ever, and nothing truly better is available, shouldn't we continue using it?

topic.title: What are some good ZeroNet blogs that are still active?
topic.body: Most blogs on ZeroNet have been inactive for years.  Does anyone know of any that are still active?

topic.title: Announcing a New ZeroNet Forum: The All-Night Bookstore and Cafe
topic.body:
I feel that both ZeroNet and the larger Internet need more cozy forums where friends can meet, engage in relaxed conversation, and perhaps practice a little creative writing.  For this purpose, I have created a new forum called the All-Night Bookstore and Cafe.  It is loosely patterned after the Midnight Pub on the Gemini network, but without the alcohol.  I intended to make the forum text-only in the style of the 1990's Internet, but I'm not quite there yet.  If the forum gets enough users to make continued effort worthwhile, I'll continue working toward getting it to be 100% text.

This forum is not a free speech zone.  It is not a place for discussing disturbing topics like politics and religion.  The only rule is to not disturb the peace.  Negative comments about the forum or other users will not be tolerated.  Trolls and obnoxious interlopers will have their names added to the "Suggested Block List" and their comment limits reduced to a level where they cannot continue to cause trouble.

All residents of ZeroNet who have been wishing for a quiet peaceful place to meet and socialize are welcome.  Enjoy.

[The All-Night Bookstore and Cafe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/13gLfTixjjktySEGHBMnmrQu4qMJpoRuXw/)

topic.title: How to Support ZeroNet and Specific ZeroNet Zites
topic.body:
I know this has been said many times before, but I am sure that we can all benefit by being reminded from time to time.  If you are not a programmer, and you value ZeroNet and specific ZeroNet zites, the best way to support them is not to give money.  It is to use them.  In the case of forums like ZeroTalk and  ZeroVoat,  using means posting and commenting on existing posts.  The only way that ZeroNet can prosper is for enough people to use it to draw others in (the network effect).  New users will not return to deserted Zites.  So, if you have found some neat zite on ZeroNet that you would like to see prosper, interact with it in whatever way it allows.  If it is a blog that allows comments, then comment.

As with the regular Internet, a big problem that ZeroNet has is that most users are lurkers who are not interacting much.  Very, very few blog creators, forum creators, or any other sort of Zite creators have the mental and emotional stamina to continue supporting a zite for years that no one interacts with.  I think this is the main reason ZeroNet has become a graveyard of abandon zites.  You have to make your presence known to motivate creators to stick around.  And an occasional expression of appreciation (non-monetary) is also very much appreciated by creators and developers.

Personally, I love ZeroNet and ZeroTalk, and I really, really want them to prosper.  So, please do more than lurk.

I would also very much appreciate your support for my two zites if they interest you at all: [ZeroTalk Tech](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EfLnw7GDXbZfJmGNoXGQ4XkuHGWkRZTMq) (now nearly two years old) and [The All-Night Bookstore and Cafe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/13gLfTixjjktySEGHBMnmrQu4qMJpoRuXw) (which has only been on ZeroNet for five days).  The second zite is especially dependent on your interaction.  In addition to being a long-term opportunity for socializing with other ZeroNet users, it was designed specifically to be an opportunity for the less technical ZeroNet users to post their own creative content.  I hope as many of you as possible will take advantage of these opportunities.

Please tell us some of your favorite ZeroNet zites in order to let others know about them, so they can support them too.

topic.title: Precipitous Drop in ZeroNet Users over the Last Two Months
topic.body:
The huge drop in users over the last two months does not seem to be just the result of people losing interest in ZeroNet.  I've been here for two years, and I've seen the number of users fluctuate up and down, sometimes by large percentages, but I've never seen anything like this.  This seems different.

I am beginning to wonder if maybe some blocking of ZeroNet is occurring.  Last night around midnight (US time), I brought up the globe that shows ZeroNet connection points (nodes? I'm not sure of the technical name other than a mix of Tor nodes and locations of users who are not using proxies), and I saw a few lights along the cost of China, but the interior was dark.  Russia was also completely dark--not a single light.  Has Putin managed to completely block Tor and ZeroNet in Russia?  Are ISP's around the  world doing something to make connecting to ZeroNet more difficult?  I have had no problem connecting, and I am seeing plenty of trackers.

Does anyone have an explanation for the drop that has been and is still occurring?

topic.title: How do You Decide which "Facts" are Real?
topic.body: Conspiracy theories abound.  Some turn out to be true, but most are not.  How do you decide which are true and which are not?  How do you decide whether the "facts" that you are being told are true?  Given the difficulty humans have in separating fact from fiction, this is a serious problem.  One thing books on critical thinking say is to focus on "smoking gun facts"--facts that show that a theory cannot possibly be true, rather than all the evidence that supports the theory, because supporting evidence may be just a coincidence.  I think this approach has flaws also.  One approach that has helped me is discussing the facts with friends who are experts.  Unfortunately, most of us don't have friends who are experts in many areas of knowledge.  I guess this is a reason to cultivate friendships with intelligent, knowledgeable people.  Any other ideas?

topic.title: Some of My Thoughts on Free Speech
topic.body:
For a network that was created to support free speech, we ZeroNet users do not seem to talk about it much.  I know this can be a difficult subject, not only to discuss but also to solidify in our own minds.  We want to be free to speak about issues that are on our minds, but we cringe sometimes when others do.  Many of us find the speech of Nazis, racists, and child pornographers deeply offensive.  That incentivizes us to criticize the offenders and to attempt to force them to leave ZeroNet.  In effect, many of us believe in free speech without really believing fully in it.  

I know in the case of child pornography, we have the additional problem of children being harmed, and that their rights should trump those of the child pornographers, so perhaps this is a bad example of a free speech issue.  Then again, for reasons that I will give below, maybe it is not.

I guess I am concerned more about the choices we make as a result of our understanding than about defining specific topics or types of speech that should be allowed to be free.  Many of us seem to want moderation on a platform that was designed specifically not to limit free speech, i.e. not to have moderation.  Moderation can be found everywhere else, and that is a large part of why we are here in the first place.  So, why would we want to bring the same system to ZeroNet that exists on the social networks from which we have fled?  That seems illogical.  It just seems to me that many of us are busy trying to destroy the gift that nofish has given us.  If we want moderation, we know exactly where to find it.  We don't need to create it here--except perhaps on a few zites in order to attract those to ZeroNet who are not yet ready to fully embrace the principles of free speech, because we hope that some day they may.

I am concerned that many of us have not yet grasped the principle that limiting the rights of one person is the same as limiting the rights of everyone, including ourselves individually.  We may not yet be aware that freedom is an obligation as well as a right.  The obligation that we have is to allow everyone the freedom that we would like to have.  In the case of free speech, this means allowing everyone to speak about anything they want--no matter how offensive--just as we would like the freedom to speak about whatever we want that may offend others.  As has been said by someone famous whose name I cannot recall, offensive speech ***is*** free speech.

Maybe part of the problem is with language.  Perhaps we should not even be using the words "us" and "them".  In talking about free speech, really, we are all them, and they are all us.  I suppose that to take this to its logical conclusion, this may even mean giving up the belief that we have the right to decide what speech should be protected and what speech should not.

I'm not trying to be preachy.  Everyone must judge for him or herself to what extent he or she is willing to support the rights of others.  I can't do that for you, and you can't do that for me.  In other words, I don't have any answers.  I'm not even sure answers exist.

Earlier in my life, I believed strongly in a religion that teaches that God gave us our free will.  Unfortunately, few in my church understood the implications of that belief.  While we said we believed that God gives everyone freedom, we were busy trying to take that freedom away.  Instead of loving others as ourselves, we were busy judging them and expecting them to be better and more Christ-like than we were ourselves.  We were expecting them to live up to standards that we were incapable of living up to.  And we did not even understand what we were doing.  Nor were we alone.  I see politicians in my country giving speeches in front of giant flags where they use words written by others who are smarter and wiser.  They talk about how great our country is because we believe in freedom for all.  But, behind the scenes they seem to be working diligently to take away the freedom they publicly espouse.  

The desire to limit others' freedom--as it pertains to things that are really none of our business and where other people are engaging in practices that hurt no one but themselves--seems to be part of the human condition.  Perhaps it is a survival mechanism.  Or perhaps none of us are intelligent enough to clearly see our own hypocrisy.  Or perhaps, we really don't want freedom.  Perhaps we love the idea of freedom but not the reality of it.  Perhaps that means we don't really deserve it.  Perhaps only the Nazi's, racists, terrorists, and child pornographers are practicing the levels of true free speech for which ZeroNet was intended.  Perhaps the rest of us should leave who are trying to limit their freedom, since we can't benefit from ZeroNet, because we don't really want freedom?  Or perhaps--hopefully--my logic is faulty.  Perhaps I an simply confusing myself about a topic I don't understand, and I am extrapolating a line of reasoning too far.

These are some of my thoughts.  What are yours?

topic.title: Nofish's Apparent Disappearance has Prompted Me to Raise the Posting-and-Comment Limits on My Zite
topic.body:
Thanks to nofish's apparent abandonment of ZeroNet, many people are now exceeding their limits on ZeroTalk, resulting in the loss of their ability to post and comment.  This has so depressed me that I have raised the limit to a very high value for everyone on the [All-Night Bookstore and Cafe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/13gLfTixjjktySEGHBMnmrQu4qMJpoRuXw/?Home).  Hopefully, no robots will appear to make me regret this decision.

The All-Night Bookstore and Cafe is moderated, so just be aware that you can be ejected for being obnoxious.

topic.title: I just added Anonymoose's patch to my ZeroNet installation
topic.body:
I decided to wait until I could no longer access ZeroNet, which finally occurred today, because I wanted to watch that happen before I patched my ZeroNet installation.  I downloaded the files here: "https://git.disroot.org/anonymoose/ZeroNet_OnionV3" and followed the instructions on that page with one correction (probably necessary for the specific version of ZeroNet that I am on).  The one correction was to use "ZeroPath/core/src/..." everywhere in place of "ZeroPath/src/...".

So, I'm guessing that any ZeroNet users who have not either added the patch or used Geekless's fork of ZeroNet are now no longer able to access ZeroNet.

I hadn't thought of that, but it makes perfect sense.  However, if I want to be uncensorable, I can create my own clearnet website too.   If the domain name provider of my clearnet website decides to revoke my domain name in order to take down my site, then I just get a new domain name with another provider under a fake identity and put my site right back up with a new domain name. Finally, the law now provides the conception of "forever ban" for a illegal site, so any copies on any domains are to be immediately blocked once noticed. [...]

1561030213_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac.body:
> [caryoscelus](#comment_163_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE): Top country: [...]

I see.  So, you are saying the locations of peers shown on the ZeroNet STATS page is just the location of TOR nodes and VPN servers that they are using.  That makes sense.  So, how do you know the true top three countries that peers are located in is the US, Russia, and China?

It probably is the middle of the night right now in China, and I'm seeing Belgium is the lowest on the list with 23 peers.  China is nowhere on the list (meaning it's less than Belgium).  Total number of peers is 2283.  So fewer than 1% are from China.  That still seems very low, even for the middle of the night.

> [yfc3nxakt](#comment_1_1EECPRXzpW95MYpBZUTLd47TofKW9xGC9e): I am a normal user from China. In our country, many connections to zeronet are blocked by GFW. A small number of users are divided into two ways, one is vpn (so users will be marked as other countries), and the other is to use nodes that are not blocked (easily subject to government review)And zeronet is just a small tool in China (possibly because the official website is blocked). Most people don't have much demand. We use ssr to connect to foreign internet.

What is "ssr"?  And what nodes are not easily blocked?  I would have thought the Chinese government would be able to block access to any IP address from inside its country.

> [klu9](#comment_184_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): @xcape2net: For me currently, China is #2 with 260 peers, at 02:50am China time. Strange there's such a difference between us.  [...]

I'm new to ZeroNet, and I don't know what you mean by, "a big tracker list provided by a Chinese ZeroNaut, IIRC".  Can you explain more about that?

> [klu9](#comment_185_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): @xcape2net: [...]

This is very interesting.  Thank you.  I'll have to try that when I get some time to play around with it.  So, who are running the trackers, and can anyone run one?  (Update: I answered my own question.  It looks like you can download the tracker software from Github (https://github.com/ZeroNetJS/zeronet-tracker).  So anyone can run a tracker. I get the impression from what I read on Github that trackers are some kind of generic things that are used on more than just ZeroNet.)  And when you say, "currently my ZeroHello reports: TRACKERS: 52/68", does that mean that there are 68 trackers in existence, or are there more?  (Update: I see from my ZeroHello: TRACKERS: 14/16.  So, I'm not connected to nearly as many as you.  This also tells me that the second number is not the total number of trackers on the planet.  So, we probably don't know how many people are currently connected to ZeroNet, because there could be many trackers that we don't know about.  But there must be a master list of trackers somewhere?) Do you know what the "file server port" does on the configuration page?

So, it sounds like this peer/tracker system means that ZeroNet is not strickly a peer-to-peer network.  It's some kind of hybrid mesh network.

> [klu9](#comment_186_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): @xcape2net:I am not an expert :) so be careful about anything I say here. [...]

Thanks for the response.  I'm thinking this tracker-peer hybrid mesh network makes ZeroNet a lot more subject to governmental control than I was thinking, because all a government has to do is take down a small number of trackers (less than 50?) within its borders (including maybe a few within bordering countries?) to take down ZeroNet--as you said China is doing.   That's a bit disappointing.

I'm wondering what hardware and internet bandwidth is required for a tracker.  If it's only telling peers how to connect to each other, then the requirements should be trivial.  But, if it is passing actual content to peers, then the requirements would be a lot heftier.

> [ssdifnskdjfnsdjk](#comment_853_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS): @xcape2net [...]

Thanks very much for the information.  I'll look into it.  

You said, "we can find big lists of tr@ckers in the clearnet, use duck.com i think these will be compatible with zeronet.."  So, trackers are something general that has been adopted for use by ZeroNet?  Do you know what other networks use these big lists of trackers?

> [ssdifnskdjfnsdjk](#comment_853_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS): @xcape2net [...]

When I try to go to duck.com, I get redirected to duckduckgo.com.  Is that where you meant to direct me?  Also, you didn't make it completely clear--are trackers and torrent trackers the same thing?

> [ssdifnskdjfnsdjk](#comment_854_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS): yes DDG. i think they are same - when i go to /Stats page i can see normal trackers which people use for torrent clients (leechersParadise, internetwariors..) are there and seems to be working.

I saw that all the trackers on the STATS page (at least the ones I could ping to get their IP addresses and, from there, look up their geographic locations) are in the EU and the United States.  I couldn't find an online list of more trackers that also gave geographic locations.  I assume that if I add trackers that are located in countries like South Africa and Australia that I would then see the peers in those countries and, therefore, see their posts?  Am I thinking about this correctly?  Maybe their posts are just relayed through trackers around the world until they finally get to the trackers I can see?  But, if that were true, then I should be able to see everything on ZeroNet while just being connected to one tracker.  So, what's the point of currently being connected to 13 trackers?  Are you aware of any tracker lists with geographic locations, so I can avoid pinging dozens or hundreds of trackers to find the ones I'm looking for?

Here are some answers to a couple of my questions that I found online.  There isn't much out there about zeronet after 2016.

This is a three-month-old Reddit post:


waic90
1 point ·
3 months ago

By the way. Today I found many zites can't update in China due to the tracker connect problem.

I tried to add 200+ trackers manually, but only 6 work ( none of them 100% success ).

I wonder if our develop team has any plan to improve the decentralization or reliability of zeronet so that it can break through the blockade by the government.



d14na
1 point ·
3 months ago

The current tracker-based system is very easily blocked by censors. I know that DHT is on the roadmap for the core developers.



----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: https://acelewis.com/blog/about-zeronet         (2016)

"When ZeroNet sends the tracker a request containing the SHA512 hash the tracker sends back a request with the IPs of the people that have that file so you can connect to them..."

"The only way for your site to go down is if everyone on your site decides not to seed (unlikely because many people/servers are set up to host all ZeroNet sites) or you get forced to use your private key to wipe the site."

"Due to the nature of ZeroNet you can go one step further and create a ZeroNet site (with the information on it) sign it and “forget” aka don’t save the private key. If you don’t have the private key then no one at all can edit the site, so no one can take it down not even you. This of course comes with the down side that you can’t update your site at all."


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: https://www.turnkeylinux.org/blog/p2p-web-hosting           (2016)


"The Intelligence Community have been flooding TOR with malicious nodes. With enough of those deducing the location of a hidden website becomes possible eventually. The higher the numbers of malicious nodes the higher the probability that a routing circuit will eventually be created comprising only the attacker's nodes. This allows the attacker to reveal the true IPs for both sides of the connections. This is called a Sybil attack.

There are probably some technical countermeasures that would make this sort of attack harder, but the kind of troublemaker who would be most likely to lead this effort has been kicked out following what looks an awful lot like a character assassination campaign by JTRIG. Probably the same people behind the allegations of sexual misconduct against Wikileaks co-founder Julian Assange.

Even if TOR wasn't being systematically compromised, keeping a hidden site hidden from determined investigators is very hard. It's easy to make mistakes."

"The main intrinsic limitation of ZeroNet is that it's less forgiving than the web with regards to unpopular content. The long tail is shorter. Beyond the handful of swarm-happy P2P sites is an empty wasteland of broken links."

---------------------------------------------------------------------


So, the bottom line of all this seems to be that (as of three months ago) the Chinese government was successfully blocking zeronet, via removing trackers and blocking TOR nodes.  And, TOR really isn't all that effective anymore against governments' efforts to discover the identities of users by running their own TOR nodes--but I already knew that.

1561066486_1HiSNH8Uh5LSRjqxtrZrBUEquny9D.body:
I agree with the people who said to use TAILS on a USB stick.  TAILS wipes every trace of everything you have done with it when you shut it down--the downside is that it isn't persistent, so you can't easily modify it as needed.  

Also, don't forget that any time you are on a network, a record of your computer's MAC address is likely being made.  If your school is doing that, you want to set your computer to create a random MAC address every time you connect to the school's network.  I believe TAILS does that automatically, but I'm not sure.

I just saw your other post where you said TOR is prohibited.  So, now I understand why you are reluctant to use TAILS.  Have you thought about a safe place to hide a USB stick, or making it look like something else (e.g. a tube of chapstick)?  

Also, I don't know if this will still work, because I haven't used this method in twenty years, and  they may have changed all the mail servers by now,  but you used to be able to send an email to a specific type of mail server to request an email that contains any (static) webpage on the internet.  http://www.faqs.org/faqs/internet-services/access-via-email    

Another thing to think about is that unsophisticated IT people (sounds like that doesn't describe your IT people) will "block" sites by blocking the DNS lookup somehow.  I have read (but not tried this method) that if that is the case, you may be able to get to a "blocked" website by typing in the IP address, instead of the URL, into your web browser.  That way no DNS server is needed.

Then there's always the semi-plausible excuse for not giving them the password for an encrypted USB stick: "I don't remember the password."  That excuse probably works better if the USB stick looks like it's 1000 years old and has "somehow" fallen behind the sofa cusions.

> [styromaniac](#comment_703_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): I wouldn't trust a for-profit proprietary technology to solve problems without becoming a con$umer trap.

I hear you, but no one is working on a viable solution to the "last mile" problem that does not involve large companies.  As long as individuals can't connect to each other directly,  without a big company's infrastructure, they can always be locked out whenever a company or government feels like shutting off their communication.  A usable mesh network using some communication like radio is the only solution.  Even that can be jammed, unfortunately.  But, although I don't agree with the way they're doing it, at least Skywire is heading in that direction.

There is a HAM radio solution to the "last mile" problem.  There are HAM radio modems, but given their low frequencies, they have correspondingly low bandwidth--plenty to relay email and ZeroTalk posts, but not great for pictures, books, music, data, and videos.  The problem with the HAM radio solution is that you need a HAM radio license, and governments are already clamping down on those.  It wouldn't take much more for them to get rid of HAM radio licenses completely.  In the end, governments can regulate any technology that we can come up with.  There could be some earth orbit solutions, but governments control what gets into orbit.

https://digdeeper.neocities.org/ghost/browsers.html highly recommended Palemoon and the uMatrix addon.

Results from my privacy testing: 
The default configuration of Palemoon failed every test on panopticlick.com and froze on ip-check.info.
Selecting more privacy settings for Palemoon caused it to pass 4 of the 5 tests on panopticlick.com (still failed the 5th test, fingerprinting)
Firefox with uMatrix was fairly private, but not perfect.
The Tor browser with extra privacy settings turned on was about as private as Firefox with uMatrix (or maybe a little better; there are so many tests on ip-check.info that it's hard to compare).
None of the above blocked fingerprinting.

1562405706_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body: I just downloaded, installed, and ran the IPFS desktop (software that gives you access to the IPFS network).  I found that downloading data from the IPFS network was glacially slow.  It took between 5 and 10 minutes to download an 800 KB Wikipedia page. If the plan for IPZN is to access ZeroNet pages using the IPFS protocol, and that access is as slow as I've just experienced, the only useful application will be in viewing small blog zites.  I can't see how it would be useful for accessing any other content on ZeroNet.
Robustness is of no value if it's too slow to use for most must things you want to do with it.

Okay, I see your point.  If nothing else works, IPFS is better than nothing.  But if anything else works at all, I wouldn't use IPFS.  What about a faster protocol?  With a faster protocol ZeroNet could be linked to other peer-to-peer networks and actually be useful for more applications all the time, not just when nothing else works.
That's what I've heard people say.  Are there good reasons to think it's actually true?
Exactly how does that make it faster?

I'm not saying we should use trackers.  I'm not an expert, so I could be completely wrong.  But it seems to me that if someone is going to put in a lot of work into this on the assumption that more peers will make IPFS run faster, that they should do some kind of analysis to make sure that is true first.  Also, the assumption that there will be more peers in the future is another assumption.  People like me who have tried using IPFS may decide that it's so slow that they are never going to use it again (as I have).  If they all decide that, there may not be more peers in the future.  I'm thinking that if someone is going to put in a lot of effort in on this, it seems a wiser choice to eliminate the two assumptions by starting out with a faster protocol.
Are you saying you've decided not to use IPFS?

I see.  Well, if that's what you want to do, go for it.  I just think a little more thought before starting on the development of software based on IPFS might pay off with more people using your solution in the long run.  But, as I said, I'm no expert.

> [diff](#comment_7_17husSAraRRvc7qRWxwA7KF7PTwjhTmxhD): Old talk: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/1669

Maybe this point has already emphasized enough, but the point made in that conversation that I thought was good was: "Dat needs an strong application-layer, and ZeroNet needs an strong storage-layer: so @pfrazee and @shortcutme , if you two really fukng cares about an open and decentralized Internet, both you should unite your efforts as each one of you haves the piece of the other side, that jointing will form an very good application/storage-layer stack that is better than IPFS (the focus is not be better than other, but to be better for users)."

Substitute any protocol in place of "Dat" that is USEFUL into that quote that you want, and his point is still valid.  I think the best thing for ZeroNet would be for it to be able to talk to other peer-to-peer networks, at least one of which doesn't use trackers.  This would provide robustness for the Chinese and at the same time progress toward an actual peer-to-peer internet that a lot of people want to use.  There are more than a million people currently using the Diaspora/Mastodon/Friendica/Pleroma network BECAUSE they are all connected to each other.

So, Web 1.0 and web 2.0 coexist today.  Mostly likely, the same will happen with Web 3.0.  We will continue seeing Web 1.0 and 2.0 sites as more and more Web 3.0 sites are appearing.  All three will coexist.  So, there will never be some point at which we now have web 3.0, even though some people may declare it to be true long after the fact.  We will just gradually have more Web 3.0 sites.  Many big companies will choose to continue to have their central servers for one reason or another, so Web 2.0 sites will never disappear completely, just like Web 1.0 sites will never disappear completely.

My thoughts on this since I created my own website have been that once we allow a certificate issuing authority to set requirements that must be met to have an https website, that authority can set the requirements so high and make them so expensive to reach that only big corporations can afford to meet the requirements.  Then, the little guy running his website from his home server can no longer have an https webs.  Then, whenever someone lands on a non-http website, Google has a browser message pop up saying, "Danger! Dangerous Website!  Extreme Security Risk!  Do you want to continue.", and 80% of people don't know any better, so they click, "no".  This is pretty much already happening.  The certificate issuing authorities just needs to keep raising the requirements steadily for another few years, and this scenario will occur.

It looks like Cloudflare may have already started working on their app.  [See their announcement last year.](https://blog.cloudflare.com/distributed-web-gateway/)  The most interesting part is this: "Today we’re excited to introduce Cloudflare’s IPFS Gateway, an easy way to access content from the InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) that doesn’t require installing and running any special software on your computer. We hope that our gateway, hosted at cloudflare-ipfs.com, will serve as the platform for many new highly-reliable and security-enhanced web applications. The IPFS Gateway is the first product to be released as part of our Distributed Web Gateway project, which will eventually encompass all of our efforts to support new distributed web technologies."

What does that sound like?

Cloudflare is already filtering IPFS.  In their [announcement](https://blog.cloudflare.com/distributed-web-gateway/), they have a section called "Dealing with Abuse".  After they say they can't modify or remove content from the IPFS, they add, "If any abusive content is found that is served by the Cloudflare IPFS gateway, you can use the standard abuse reporting mechanism described here."

So, they are already using their website "gateway" to IPFS to control what you can see on IPFS !!!

Also, each Zite is owned by someone who has to be able to stop others from modifying their zite (centralization by design).  I think that's why there are so many zites that haven't been updated since like 2017.  A couple of website owners have died and others have apparently just lost interest.  Also, there is the bit-torrent tracker issue.  ZeroNet requires bit-torrent trackers to function (although other people say there are other methods of connecting, which I haven't investigated yet). Then there is ZeroID centralization; although people have pointed out that there are other ways of creating an ID on ZeroNet.  The bottom line for me is that ZeroNet is a combination of centralized and decentralized software.  Hopefully, it will become more decentralized in the future (like with IPFS, DAT, CJDNS, etc.), and there have been many, many discussions on ZeroTalk about this, so it's nothing new to people who have been here for a while. So, here is the summary of how to install the Python 3 version of ZeroNet on Linux Mint 17:

sudo add-apt-repository ppa:jonathonf/python-3.6
sudo apt update
sudo apt-get install python3.6
wget https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py
sudo python3.6 get-pip.py
sudo -H python3.6 -m pip install -r ZeroNet-py3/requirements.txt

Then run it ZeroNet with this command:

python3.6 /home/mint/ZeroNet-py3/zeronet.py --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150 --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151

Be sure to substitute your path to zeronet.py above.

Then Start the TOR broswer and type the URL: 127.0.0.1:43110

You may also have to go to the TOR browser settings/preferences/network proxy and select "manual proxy configuration" and "SOCKS Host" 127.0.0.1  and "No proxy for": 127.0.0.1 .

> [gitcenter](#comment_537_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Actually, that's specified on ZeroNet repository home page I believe :)

You're right.  Sorry I missed that.  It would have saved me a big headache.

1565403304_1D9oYXWZH2S55PeoCFDKTqq8roNXq.body:
This works for me on Linux Mint 17:

In the TOR browser settings/preferences/network proxy, select "manual proxy configuration" and "SOCKS Host" 127.0.0.1 and Port 9150 and "No proxy for": 127.0.0.1 .

Start the TOR browser and type the URL: 127.0.0.1:43110

THEN, and only then, run ZeroNet with this command:

python3.6 /home/mint/ZeroNet-py3/zeronet.py --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150 --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151

Be sure to substitute your path to zeronet.py above and whatever version of python 3 you are using.  Also, I use the list of trackers from here: http://127.0.0.1:43110/15CEFKBRHFfAP9rmL6hhLmHoXrrgmw4B5o/

If using the python 2 version of ZeroNet:

python /home/mint/ZeroBundle/zeronet.py --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150 --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151

Having to take the additional step of setting TOR Always doesn't make sense to me.  One would think if you are connecting to a peer who isn't using TOR, your IP address would be hidden just as it is when you connect to any clearnet website.

> [0nullz](#comment_14_12XcKUGvjkDZ5ufLFESyYLYXgELagrHyxz): What backs crypto is the level of trust that is gained by the network in completing it's designed function, which is to replace SWIFT. [...]

SWIFT is neither a currency nor a store of value.  It does not make sense to compare crytocurrency to SWIFT.  The fractional banking system is not a currency; it is a lending system by which more currency may be created.  You are comparing different things again.  

The reason the dollar or mark or yen in my pocket or in my bank account is worth something is because there is a limited supply.  The supply may be large, but it is limited.  The reason an ounce of gold has more value than a dollar is in large part because there are fewer ounces of gold than dollars.  The reason sand is cheap is because there is a nearly unlimited supply.  An infinite supply of cryptocurrency can be generated; therefore, in a free, rational market, it will not have a long-term, non-zero value as an infinite supply is generated.

> [aim64c](#comment_35_17GmcqqqJdfEM4DkRsqvvprifPVwYx575h): Except they can't.Sure, I can create my own cryptocurrency, but it has zero relevance to any other cryptocurrency on the market. [...]

If 47 people each create their own version of bitcoin with the exact same algorithms as bit coin, call them bitcoin1 through bitcoin47, how will you decide which one to invest in?  If you decide to invest in bitcoin27 and I decide to invest in bitcoin5, neither of us will be investing in the original bitcoin.  That is inflation, just the same as if we were talking about dollars or marks or yen.  There is a finite investment pool being spread over more investment units.

> [0nullz](#comment_15_12XcKUGvjkDZ5ufLFESyYLYXgELagrHyxz): Comparing crypo to SWIFT makes perfect sense since it is not a physical currency, it is not a paper legal tender or a coin and it's design makes systems like SWIFT obsolete since it also is a financial network. The p2p consensus network enforced by cryptographic standards not central authorities make it an apolitical system. Further increasing the value of it's network. [...]

Nothing you've said here makes sense.  But, why don't you tell me why you think crypto was created?  I thought is was to be a replacement for the fiat currencies we have now.  In other words, it was supposed to be a store of value, a medium of exchanges, and a unit of account.  I've shown that it can't be used as store of value, because an infinite quantity of it can be produced.  It's fine as a medium of exchange.  It's questionable as a unit of account, because the value of it fluctuates so wildly.  But it could possibly be stabilized somehow to make it a better unit of account.  So, while it could replace the SWIFT system, that doesn't mean it could replace our current currencies as a store of value.  We would need something else to act as a store of value.  We could use gold-backed crypto for that.  But, governments (who I'm sure are fully aware of the point I'm making) have already shown that they will shut down any real-asset-based cryptocurrency.  This brings up another problem with bitcoin that is off of our topic of discussion--it is not immune to regulation, and anything that can be regulated can be destroyed.  As the US Supreme Court said decades ago, "the power to tax is the power to destroy".
