> [90w8fuiosrhui](#comment_29_11TbhWmLbceRuHERFahR7cdrTSBN4MN4F): It looks like that to me. Bitcoin, Ethereum, Monero and a few other cryptos will survive.

I've given what I think are very good reasons for thinking no cryptocurrency will survive over the long term.  I've not heard good reasons for why you think they will.  I'm open-minded and willing to listen to anyone who can refute my arguments based on something other than feelings and wishes.  Believe me, I would love to have some form of currency that could replace the thoroughly corrupt system we have in place today.  I would love for cryptocurrencies to be the solution.  But, given the arguments that I've made against cryptocurrencies, I just don't see that they are capable of doing that.  Depending on public perceptions of cryptocurrencies, they could survive for another 10 years, perhaps another 100 years, but eventually they are doomed to fail (at least as a store of value), because they are incompatible with the fundamental economic principle of supply and demand.

While ideals, like giving power to the people, can be a basis for a moment, they cannot sustain a movement that is economically infeasible.  And, it is a basic fact of life that anything tangible can be taken away by a government.  I have explained that governments are fully capable of regulating crytocurrencies out of existence, and from the evidence I see, I am fairly sure that they are working hard on doing just that.  They have already made it very difficult to exchange fiat currency for cyrptocurrencies without identifying ourselves, which means cryptocurrency users can be tracked.  And, as I said, they have succeeded in preventing cryptocurrencies from being backed by tangible assets.  They are already taxing fiat-to-crypto transactions.  Once a government has the power to tax something, they can tax it as much as they want, even a 100% tax if they choose, hence, "the power to tax is the power to destroy".

If you want to invest in things governments can't take from you, invest in education, friendships, life experiences, and other things that are intangible.

> [90w8fuiosrhui](#comment_32_11TbhWmLbceRuHERFahR7cdrTSBN4MN4F): Exactly, thats why quality lifetime, fewer open-minded friends etc. is so important to me. btw i really enjoy reading your posts

Thanks.

> [0nullz](#comment_16_12XcKUGvjkDZ5ufLFESyYLYXgELagrHyxz): They have done a real bang up job enforcing and regulating copyright concerning digital content. Until they can do this right then they may have a shot at regulating crypto networks.  [...]

They are doing more than just regulating centralized exchanges.  They are making it very difficult for anyone to buy cryptocurrency with fiat currency without identifying themselves first. The one exception is when the buyer and seller meet face-to-face (which almost never happens; see the sparsity of face-to-face sellers on Bisq).  This means that they can tax essentially all exchanges of cryptocurrency for fiat currency.  In fact, the US Internal Revenue Service is already mailing out [notices of taxes due](https://www.zdnet.com/article/irs-begins-tax-hunt-for-unreported-cryptocurrency-profits/) for exchanges taking place as far back as 2013 (meaning interest penalties apply).  Being able to tax something is a large part of the definition of being in controlling of it.

Another method of exchanging crypto for cash anonymously via an exchange was to walk into a bank and deposit cash into the crypto seller's account.  But, last year banks started putting into place rules that prevent anyone from depositing cash into an account (even their own) without showing identification.  So, this is just one example of governments finding ways of controlling crytocurrencies by regulation that has nothing to do with regulating crypto exchanges.

The problem with decentralized exchanges is that the buyer and seller have to trust each other enough to make the transaction.  How do you develop trust?  Right now, most sellers of crypto insist that buyers identify themselves.   Anyone who has used an exchange should have become aware of this.  The risky alternative is to mail cash in an envelope to someone you don't know.  Paxful (a centralized service) has this as one option.  Strangely, when I tried to do this (the first and only time I tried it), they blocked my account and demanded that I identify myself before they would unblock it.  However, someone will likely solve this problem and make decentralized exchanges viable.  That could make cryptocurrencies a viable medium of exchange--unless governments can find some way of counteracting it, like doing away with all anonymous cash (at which point we could barter goods for crypto (like on Openbazaar), which brings up another set of problems for doing this anonymously).  Remember that I said, for reasons I've already mentioned, that cryptocurrencies cannot work unless the buyer and seller can be anonymous.  I'm pretty sure Satoshi understood this.

But this still leaves the problem of cryptocurrencies not being a store of value.  This is why they shouldn't be used as investment vehicles.

> [aim64c](#comment_37_17GmcqqqJdfEM4DkRsqvvprifPVwYx575h):  Even if you wanted to argue that clones could create an inflationary principle, the math works against you. If we are using Bitcoin, then there will only ever be x bitcoins. Creating one clone gives you the ability to, at best, double the currency supply and thereby half the purchasing power. However, a second clone only reduces the purchasing power to a third. A fourth clone to a quarter, and so on. You would need to not only create these clones, but you would also need to persuade investment into them sufficiently to split the market cap. Each one would, also, need to be recognized by exchanges and/or retailers for direct exchange. Why should I, running my own business, accept CloneCoin 20 and keep its exchange rate updated when it's functionally equivalent to Coin1? You would need to create and persuade users to invest equally into CloneCoin 0-99 to get to the same degree of inflation we have seen under the federal reserve.

This is a reasonable argument, and I can only respond to it by giving my speculation about how people would react to your scenario.  So, let me argue semi-logically from the other direction.  If there were in the world only one cryptocurrency, say bitcoin1, and I look at that and say, "Wow, bitcoin1 is really valuable.  Why can't I just create another 100 million units of cryptocurrency identical to it called bitcoin2?  I could make a pile of money, because people will look at bitcoin1 which sells for $20000 per unit and see my identical product that only sells for $2 per unit and say to themselves, 'Why should I pay $20000 for something that I can get for only $2?'".  I think investors would agree with that and be willing to invest in it.  As a result, exchanges would be willing to make their customers happy by carrying it.    There is no reason that, seeing my success, other people won't create bitcoin 3-99.  I would guess that after about bitcoin6, people would realize what is happening and ask the exchanges not to carry bitcoin7-99.  At that point others will step in and create other exchanges for bitcoin7-20, and then bitcoin21-55, and so forth.  As long as there is a financial incentive to create the next bitcoin version, someone will, and someone else will create an exchange for it.  The real problem is that this will continue on until politicians decide to regulate it.  But, if bitcoin can't be regulated, as some still claim despite all the evidence to the contrary, then regulation cannot work and the number of bitcoin variants will continue to grow until there is no more profit to be made by another variant.  And that point will be reached when there are so many variants that they are worth nothing.  In other words, it will not happen any time soon, but it will happen.   On the other hand, if bitcoin can be regulated, then it will.  Once it is regulated it is under the control of a centralized authority.  Since the whole point of bitcoin in the first place is to prevent it from being under the control of a centralized authority, bitcoin will be no better as far as the crypto enthusiasts are concerned than the dollar, mark, or yen.  I could go on with my speculation and explain why that is true, despite the value of the blockchain, but I don't think there is a point, if you don't see the value of my speculative argument up to this point.

> [aim64c](#comment_38_17GmcqqqJdfEM4DkRsqvvprifPVwYx575h): My counter to this is that we see nearly the exact opposite behavior from people/customers in practice....

I appreciate the well-thought-out response.  Perhaps we will just have to agree to disagree and watch to see what happens.  

I do have one example, however, of another tool that spreads on the basis of popularity in a similar way as cryptocurrencies.  That is Linux distributions.  Currently there are over 700.  I was not able to find how many people use which distribution, but I was able to find an indicator of the popularity of each distribution (at least the top 100), which I think may be fairly good indicator of the relative popularities of the Linux distributions.  Look at the right side of the page on https://distrowatch.com/ (scroll down a little to "Page Hit Rankings").  I haven't computed any statistics, but just looking at the rankings, I see that if I normalize the popularity of the  Linux distributions with the most popular, "My Linux", having the value "1.0", a few of the others look like this:

Rank:1, MyLinux, value: 1.0
Rank: 2, Mandrake, value: 0.60
Rank: 3, Mint, value: 0.44
Rank: 4, Ubuntum, value: 0.31
Rank: 5, Debian, value: 0.30
Rank: 6, Elementary, value: 0.30
Rank: 7, Solus, value: 0.24
Rank 8, Fedora, value: 0.22
Rank 9, Zorin, value: 0.18 
Rank: 10, openSUSE, value: 0.18
Rank: 15, CentOS, value: 0.13
Rank: 20, POP! OS, value: 0.10
Rank: 30, Alpine, value 0.07
Rank: 50, Kodachi, value 0.047
Rank: 75, Clonezilla, value: 0.032
Rank: 100, LibraELEC, value: 0.0255

You can also see from https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1b/Linux_Distribution_Timeline.svg that the creation of new Linux Distributions does not appear to be slowing down.

You could argue that the factors that determine the usage of Linux distributions are different than those that determine cryptocurrency usage, even though both probably have much in common.  But, one thing the popularity of Linux distributions suggests to me is 1) that people are capable of making more than just five or six popular, and 2) which distributions are popular is changing all the time.  If the same is true of cryptocurrencies, this would mean that even if you pick a winner initially to invest in, 5, 10, 20 years from now it could easily be an out-of-favor looser.  This means that if cryptocurrencies follow the same trend as Linux, they are still not a good long-term investment. (I think following a Linux distribution trend is an optimistic scenario, because I still think they are more likely to go to near zero value.)

I should also point out that that there have been over 700 Linux distributions created in about 25 years, and Linux has very little economic incentive backing it.  There have been over 2000 cryptocurrencies created in about 10 years, thanks, I believe, to the economic incentive.  So, the number of cryptocurrencies are growing faster.  I don't know if they are coming into and falling out of favor faster than Linux distributions, but that could change.

I guess we will just have to wait and see what happens.  It should be interesting in the short term to see what happens with Facebook's new cryptocurrency, especially to see how much of bitcoin's market share it manages to take away.

Here is an article that I happened to find today that talks about the lack of privacy in bitcoin and some approaches to using it more privately.  [Bitcoin Anonymity Guide 2019: How to use BTC like a straight up G](https://www.coincache.net/2019/01/02/bitcoin-anonymity-guide-2019-how-to-use-btc-like-a-straight-up-g/?v=7516fd43adaa)

1566570350_1Dssbq2y2JDD14aojGG9RX3d5EPpw.body: In addition to its many problems, Religion has some benefits that people who have no experience with it will never understand.

My feeling about religion is that it's about mystery.  When mysteries are replaced with knowledge, the religion that we used to explain the mystery is replaced by knowledge.  But I expect there will always be mysteries remaining that will be fertile grounds for religion.  The more we learn, and the more enlightened we become, the more enlightened our religion becomes.  Carl Sagan defined God as the laws of nature.  I suspect that was not just a euphemism for atheism.  I suspect that he was as serious and committed to understanding his god as some fundamentalists are to understanding theirs.  If religion really is about mystery, then religion is not disappearing, it's just changing names and changing forms.

I can't disagree with much, if anything, that you've said.  I would just add that religion's sins of the past and the present are those of spiritually immature people, either unknowingly making mistakes, or knowingly using other's religious beliefs for their own ends.  None of that is the fault of religion (the striving to understand mysteries).  It is the fault of spiritually immature people.  When you say, "Christianity teaches ...", what you really mean is, those who call themselves Christians teach...  Christianity, itself, is what Christ taught.  The two are not always the same thing.

I love ZeroNet because there are people here who think like me.  I was just reading some of the Windows horror stories posted on the [Why I Prefer Linux](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Aiq4P8bh1f9pPxQz9MA2Z1cDkYaUGjEPn/) zite.  It gives me a warm fuzzy feeling to know there are other people who can understand why I have still not migrated to Windows 10 and don't ever plan to.  

I also smiled when I saw Quantumkitty's post that she had just bought her ***first*** micro SD card.

I also love the fact that posts hang around ***forever***.

People on ZeroNet are not afraid to say things that can get them deplatformed on the corporate-controlled clearnet.  Someone just expressed his opinion about elections being rigged.  The facts are 1) voting machine code in the US is designed to be secret, 2) the US voting machine companies are run by people with criminal records, 3) US voting machines have been shown to be easy to hack, and 4) there seems to be no accountability.  In my opinion, if it looks like a duck, quacks like a duck, and walks like a duck, it is a duck.  I can be banned for saying that on social media platforms in the US.  I have had a very popular article pulled from Hacker News for expressing my political opinion--even though many people post articles on many other topics on Hacker News without being pulled.  Not here on ZeroNet!

> [xan](#comment_6_1ATbMGy3hSpTHeHfkmX6kNRn2kbRT7fTHY): You should tell us about couple of changes or maybe dozen :-)

I'll just summarize by saying that, as I've learned more about people, I've become more accepting and religiously liberal.  I no longer believe that a heaven and hell make sense, because *ultimately*, happiness has nothing to do with what is happening around us.  It's about what is happening within us.  I've abandoned my "magical thinking" concerning religion and accepted for now that life is the way it is, and no outside force can, or should, "save" a person.  As I see it, only the individual can do that for himself.  I don't want to go into a long-winded and ultimately useless explanation of what I mean by salvation.  Religion for me now is more personal and more about admitting that what I know is nothing in comparison to what I don't know.  I realize that I've been wrong in the past about a lot of things, and I try not to take my beliefs nearly as seriously.  They are a work in progress.

> [xan](#comment_11_1ATbMGy3hSpTHeHfkmX6kNRn2kbRT7fTHY): Hey, folks! This discussion is about your discovering and your feelings when you find something new in this world.

There are a few personal stories that people who I've known over the years have told me--things like near-death experiences, out-of-body experiences, and even freakier stuff.  But if you don't believe what's written in books about those types of experiences, then there is no reason that you would trust me, an anonymous second-hand source.

> [xan](#comment_12_1ATbMGy3hSpTHeHfkmX6kNRn2kbRT7fTHY): Yes, I get your point here. At the same time personally I'm more interested in experience which you can prove. If we talk about near-death experiences or say UFO invasion it's ok until you can prove it, tell how your life changed after that, with obvious result.

There is no way to prove anything, including the "fact" that you and I exist.  There is only strong evidence, never absolute proof.  I'm not talking about a preponderance of evidence that is accepted as proof in a courtroom.  If someone chooses not to believe something, there is no level of proof that can change their mind.  So, there is no point in wasting effort on it.  My personal view is that if someone really wanted to know the truth, they most likely already would, because it is little more than their desire not to know that keeps them from accepting the strong evidence that would convince them.

Good points.  I think the bottom line on most of what you said is that there is a tremendous amount of research that would have to be done to answer some of those questions.  And some may be inherently unanswerable.  I could give speculative answers, but without any real knowledge backing them.  If we are living in a simulation, we may be able to speculate about the purpose for it, but we can probably never know for sure unless the simulations "gods" reveal it to use.  Or, maybe they already have, and we didn't recognize the revelation.  Or, maybe the revelation would spoil the experiment being conducted via the simulation.

I think there are some telling facts, like the reality of the quantization of space (Heizenberg's uncertainty principle), the quantization of time, the fact that many scientist now model physical processes in terms of information (like the evaporation of a black hole, for instance).   Until recently we thought we were living in an analog world.  Now we know it's actually a digital world.  Why should that be so?  I don't know the answer to that question, but in order for this to be a simulation, it would have to be so.  Proof of this being a simulation might have to come by digging down to the point where we understand at the sub, sub atomic level what matter and space really are and see something that would be impossible outside of a simulation.  

One of the reasons I like ZeroNet so much is that I "meet" people here who ask questions like these.

> [randomshits](#comment_186_1CuFETj5LtyEduzaoAcdv9sMAQtYRqjqDY):  Nothing can be hidden, concealed, or otherwise buried in the code without risking discovery.  [...]

One thing I can say from having several "peer" reviews of code that I've written over the years is that peers don't put in the time that they should looking for errors.  I've had several peer reviews of my code in which no one found anything.  Then, after the peer review, I found more bugs.   So, peer reviews don't have much value to people who are conscientiously writing their code.  The only value they may have is catching people who are either incompetent or are not making a good-faith effort to write good code.

> [randomshits](#comment_187_1CuFETj5LtyEduzaoAcdv9sMAQtYRqjqDY): Peer reviews failing to catch errors that may have the ability to cause exploits is a totally different subject than someone saying "Open source software is full of potential backdoors unless you check the code and compile it yourself." ...

You're probably right.  I guess my point is to disagree with the opinion that I heard expressed that just the fact that a piece of code is open source almost by definition means that it has been gone over with a fine-tooth comb by many knowledgeable people.   What I'm saying is that even when knowledgeable people are PAID to go over a piece of code, that doesn't mean that they do a good job.  So, I imagine that when people are not being paid they are even less interested in reviewing other peoples' code.

1575880894_1JszzaxuPyozejWGkm7VyEEkXNCj5.body:
Here is the easy way to do that:


    Start Tor Browser.
    Browse to about:config.
    Enter network.proxy.no_proxies_on into the "Search:" box.
    Double-click the network.proxy.no_proxies_on line that appears.
    Enter 127.0.0.1 as the value of this preference.
    Click "OK".

You only have to do this once, not every time you start TOR!

> [planespherev4](#comment_28_1KSMTkAKXzbiXa7d2HWy3rNVSUJDXExpXg): It tried it, but it feels a little claustrophobic. Don't know why.

After spending a couple of hours browsing through the Aether subforums, I understand what you mean.  There aren't all that many posts in the vast majority of subforums.  Part of that may be due to the fact that posts are removed after six months.  But I think part is just due to the fact that Aether has too many subforums.  The result is that  you get the feeling of visiting a collection of mostly uninhabited islands, instead of a well-populated mainland.  Aether needs either fewer subforums or one "general" subforum where users go to post on any topic they want.  I think we've seen a similar phenomenon with ZeroVoat.  ZeroNet just does not have enough traffic to sustain active and ongoing conversations on a large number of separate topics.  ZeroTalk is a much more appropriate forum for  ZeroNet's current size.  Speaking of that, where have all the ZeroTalk users gone over the last month or two?

Having said that, however, I have to say that Aether looks like a geek's paradise.  Some of the most active subforums are Meta (a discussion about Aether itself), FOSS, Distributed Networks, and Linux.  In that way, Aether reminds me of ZeroNet when I joined it a year ago.  Most of the discussion on ZeroNet then was on technical topics, much of it just a bit over my head, but it was fun to read.

I was surprised to learn recently that a Raspberry Pi 3 is about at powerful as an Atom processor, and a Raspberry Pi 4 is about as powerful as a Core 2 processor.  See: https://magpi.raspberrypi.org/articles/raspberry-pi-4-specs-benchmarks   and   http://www.roylongbottom.org.uk/linpack%20results.htm . Why do you think you need 16 GB of RAM?  If you are currently using Apache, you could get by with a lot less RAM by running Lighttpd or Nginx.  You may be able to switch webserver software and use a Raspberry Pi 4.  USB drives are  pretty fast on the Raspberry Pi 4.

1595147052_14ADWoY886HnM8jPeipXarxAfyQAN.body: One of the problems with a distributed network is that the limits of individual computers on the network translate to the whole network.  Since ZeroNet users have limited hard drive space and limited bandwidth on their Internet connections, most of them have to choose what contents they find most important to seed.  I for one do not seed zites whose primary content are long cat videos and other things that can be found on the open Internet.  I prefer to seed text-only zites or zites without many pictures.

1595502249_1BFC6WPRFTMXJzb687o2bvFhgt3HL.body:
Just for he fun of it, I'll take a stab at responding.

1. Neither is wrong.  If I were a judge, I would say that one person's rights don't trump the other's.  So, I would find in favor of the muslim woman.
2.  No.  I don't think gender balance matters.  What matters is empathy and a willingness to understand other's points of view.
3. I would let the people of Berkley make the decision at the ballot box.
4. Assuming you are talking about percentages of of Asians, and not total numbers, I would guess that two factors are at play.  The first is that Asians seem to be better socialized than whites in the US.  They also value education.  The second is that studies performed back in the days when it was politically acceptable to study the intelligence of races found that Asians and Jews were one sigma (about 15 I.Q. points) smarter than whites.  More intelligent, better educated people tend not to get caught by the system as much as less intelligent ones.  So, any supposed racism in the system is a red herring, since Asians don't have nearly as much contact with it in the first place.
5. This one makes me tired.  I'll just repeat the proverb that those who live by the sword die by the sword.  I have nothing intelligent to say here.
6. Men's and women's events have historically been separated because nearly everyone realizes that men and women have significantly different physical abilities.  We also separate most events into age groups for the same reason.  So, we separate people into groups to make the events more interesting for the spectators.  Why would we change that for surgically modified, steroid enhanced, or any other group of people?
7. Employers hire people, largely because they hope to make money off of their work.  When employers don't plan to work closely with the people they hire, they will simply hire the people they feel are most profitable to hire.  In one job, athletic ability is more important.  For another, intelligence is more important.  For another, docility is more important.  For another, beauty is more important.  Etc.  When employers hire people that they will be working with closely, they tend to hire people who will not only make them money but also who they think they can get along with better.  Often employers don't know just by interviewing people who will make them the most money or who they will get along with better.  So, a lot of trial and error occurs.
8. See the answer to number 4.
9. See the answers to number 4 and number 5.
10. See the answer to number 7.  The question should not be which system is more fair.  The question should be which system results in the most enjoyment for the audience that is paying to see the performances.

> [otbtechnologies3](#comment_41_12QcU9x7iK1XjguRKQKKhyc6ErguzYMkRc): Once people realize the importance of Mesh Networks in protecting their Constitutional Rights if the traditional internet becomes censored as is happening at an ever accellerating rate in the USA, then there will be plenty of willing participants. [...]

People will not spend around $100 on a device that they cannot use to connect to a mesh network because there are few or no other devices within range.  For example, I would love to connect to the goTenna network, but I will not pay $189 for two units when no others are within range of my home.  And, I do understand the value of mesh networks in protecting my constitutional rights.  I also understand what is happening to the Internet that is changing it an a way that [takes my free speech away](https://landshark.io/2020/08/16/web-by-google.html).  The only way a useful mesh network can be deployed is if thousands of people all sign up at the same time to be part of it.  That only happens when they have no other alternative ISP's.

Well, I hope it does succeed, because I would certainly love to be part of a globe-spanning mesh network that provides privacy for everyone.  But, I doubt it will happen, unless some billionaire like Elon Musk backs it.  Anyway, good luck.

1620417095_17ufjt7e9DRsavS6AADWoGpiutSp8.body: Despite the fact that Veracrypt is opensource, it may have been tampered with.  There are other examples of opensource software with subtle security flaws.  The least likely hard drive encryption program to have been tampered with is Trucrypt 7.1a.

> [n37p33r](#comment_1_1C6gAPEiSgWRPes1bmpFhWcKGyyT2WMTiX): use veracrypt or gnu-privacy-guard(known as gpg).TrueCrypt isn't FOSS or OSS.

NO, Truecrypt is not FOSS or OSS, but it has passed two independent audits.

> [n37p33r](#comment_2_1C6gAPEiSgWRPes1bmpFhWcKGyyT2WMTiX): Right, but Truecrypt is a discontinued projectVeraCrypt is a fork of TrueCrypt, much better and safer.

The problem with encryption software that has been shown to be true over and over again is that it can be compromised in subtle ways.   We now have a LOT of information about methods the NSA uses to compromise commercial encryption software.  The bottom line is that just because development of a software package is ongoing does NOT mean that it is more secure than Truecrypt, because the NSA injects NEW compromises into code when the old ones are detected and corrected.

See:
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/sep/05/nsa-gchq-encryption-codes-security
https://blog.cryptographyengineering.com/2013/09/06/on-nsa/
https://www.wired.com/2013/09/nsa-backdoored-and-stole-keys/
https://foreignpolicy.com/2016/10/04/how-american-companies-enable-nsa-surveillance/
https://theintercept.com/2018/06/25/att-internet-nsa-spy-hubs/

> [n37p33r](#comment_4_1C6gAPEiSgWRPes1bmpFhWcKGyyT2WMTiX): Actually it means that.VeraCrypt is safer than TrueCrypt because it have less security issues.VeraCrypt fixed lots of known security problems witch still exist on TrueCrypt and not only NSA, anybody can use them to attack to you. [...]

None of those are significant issues.    However, I agree that Veracrypt having SHA-256 is nice.  A cold boot attack works because of hardware issues, not software.  And it only works when the attacker has physical access to a running computer or a computer that has been shut down just seconds before and still holds data in RAM.

But, we don't know how many NEW vulnerabilities have been introduced into Veracrypt that were not in Truecrypt.  One thing we do know about Trucrypt, however, is that at least as of 2013, the NSA had not been able to crack it.  We know that, because Edward Snowden provided the proof.  Until we get another Edward Snowden, we cannot say the same about Veracrypt.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_286_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): If the NSA is a credible threat in your threat model you aren't a part of this conversation. The NSA doesn't give two shits about what any of us are doing, if they did they would blow your computer open without you even knowing it. Do what you can to be secure for sure, but know that if a nation state is after your data for whatever purpose, they are assuredly going to get it.

True.  However, as recent events have highlighted, what the NSA has today, Internet thieves will have tomorrow.  And we really have no way of knowing what they have until they have possibly had it for years.  This is a complicated issue.  I feel that Truecypt is still the safest way to go, but if you want to chose Veracrypt, who am I to dissuade you.

> [inis](#comment_1_16zLpbqTz9hpy6E2oH3y7tHNiTyVsB4RiQ): As a non-tech person, ZeroNet is the easiest darknet I managed to install and run -- uncompress the archive, copy its content into a USB key, double click the executable -- but in my opinion it is still a bit too difficult for normal people. [...]

I have heard many people voice many of the same concerns about ZeroNet.  I'm glad you haven't given up on it like so many others.  To respond to your comment about getting Tor to work reliably on Linux, I always follow this process to get Tor ALWAYS mode to work, and I haven't had any problems since I learned it:

1. Start the TOR browser and type the URL: 127.0.0.1:43110

2. THEN, and only then, run ZeroNet with this command:

python3.6 /your_path/ZeroNet-py3/zeronet.py --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150 --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151

Be sure to substitute your path to zeronet.py above and whatever version of python 3 you are using. Also, I use the list of trackers from here: http://127.0.0.1:43110/15CEFKBRHFfAP9rmL6hhLmHoXrrgmw4B5o/

If using the python 2 version of ZeroNet:

python /your_path/ZeroBundle/zeronet.py --tor_proxy 127.0.0.1:9150 --tor_controller 127.0.0.1:9151

Part of your problem may also be that different versions of the Tor browser work differently.  I am using Tor browser 10.0.17, and this is what works for me:

    Start Tor Browser.
    Browse to about:config.
    Enter network.proxy.no_proxies_on into the "Search:" box.
    Double-click the network.proxy.no_proxies_on line that appears.
    Enter 127.0.0.1 as the value of this preference.
    Click "OK".

You only have to do this once, not every time you start TOR.  I believe this has been the way this works since about version 8.0 of the Tor browser.

I hope that helps.

> [houtje](#comment_77_1HV7aMJLo3XMuij1h17kP12ZYvp1Y8EzvA): technically, how would they even go about this? How does an ISP block anything? There is no centralised server and/or domain. Perhaps I'm too much a technical retard but to me it seems that the point of ...

They have ways, and we have discussed them here over the years.  I won't give all the details--several of which are in the early postings on [ZeroTalk Tech](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EfLnw7GDXbZfJmGNoXGQ4XkuHGWkRZTMq), though you have to scroll way, way down to get to them.  You can also start with this [Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_censorship#Technical_censorship).  The technical methods are:  DNS poisoning, blocking access to IPs, analyzing and filtering URLs, inspecting filter packets, and resetting connections.  China began blocking zeronet.io, perhaps four years ago.  China and Russia do block Tor exit nodes and torrent trackers.  Some in China have had to resort to Tor bridge nodes to circumvent this.  And, I assume they are using other methods that they won't discuss here for obvious reasons.  So, it can be done, and it is being done.  The only question is, how well is it being done?  I can only guess, but Russia being completely dark is troubling.  Over the years, we have had many russians posting on ZeroNet.

1630138791_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body: I'm seeing all the content on that site.  I also have a ZeroTalk clone, and the only time I ever had a problem with it was when I left a single comma out of data/users/content.json.  My only constructive suggestion would be to go back through all your changed files and switch files that you modified with the original cloned versions until the problem goes away.  Make sure you make the changes with your version of ZeroNet inactive.  Not having ZeroNet turned off was what prevented me from easily finding my problem.

Another way to regenerate the private key from the master seed is to use the command:

zeronet.py cryptGetPrivatekey <master_seed> <site_address_index>

The master seed comes from the "master_seed" line in the ZeroNet-py3/data/users.json file, and the site address index comes from the "address_index" line in the ZeroNet-py3/data/<new website data file>/content.json file.

No wonder nontechnical people have such a hard time on ZeroNet.

> [bats](#comment_132_1QvU5RXqw5mjgR3BZV5rkc2ju6NHXpGnp): To the best of my knowledge, no one has been kicked off zeronet ever, not could they be. Wouldn't that suggest that free speech is doing fine here?

I'm not saying free speech on ZeroNet is in danger.  I'm just thinking that maybe we could improve it.  However, these are just thoughts.  I'm not saying they are right, or that I know what I'm talking about.  I posted this, because on a platform that is designed for free speech we don't talk very much about it.  And I feel that some of us are missing the whole point of ZeroNet when we talk about adding moderation to make ZeroNet look like the rest of the Internet.  I'm just hoping to start us talking more about these issue more often.

I'm not really concerned about anti-vax issues.  I'm just trying to show that free speech is more nuanced and complicated than we understand.  I don't claim to be especially knowledgeable about it or that my views are better than other peoples, because I don't think they are.  Where free speech is concerned I think I'm in the dark as much as most people.  I do know, however, that the more I think and talk about a principle--free speech or otherwise--the more I learn about it.  And I think free speech is something we all need to learn more about.

 "user_contents": {
  "cert_signers": {
   "08chan": ["1NwwLdiFBcVAA4jXQ712ZtQfDHEMvk8BiD"],
   "cryptoid.bit": ["18143WPue3rQykNaopx5KJKzYmaYhCjqhv"],
   "kaffie.bit": ["1KH5BdNnqxh2KRWMMT8wUXzUgz4vVQ4S8p"],
   "kxoid.bit": ["12F5SvxoPR128aiudte78h8pY7mobroG6V"],
   "nanasi": ["16KzwuSAjFnivNimSHuRdPrYd1pNPhuHqN"],
   "zeroid.bit": ["1iD5ZQJMNXu43w1qLB8sfdHVKppVMduGz"],
   "zeroverse.bit": ["1HPgDoReCFtE9qy71hnp55ksBVvV1gHJLQ"],
   "zv.anonymous": ["1J1c7eML6uMwDU4uiKbKRxoqxGP6WMFMvb"]
  },
...

By the way, are there any I'm missing?  I intentionally left out "millchan": ["1NwwLdiFBcVAA4jXQ712ZtQfDHEMvk8BiD"], because it prevented my zite from working.

Here are the decentralized networks I have tried.  Tor (probably the best, other than ZeroNet).  Aether (not much traffic).  I2P (hard to use)  IPFS (most sites are unreachable most of the time; may have improved lately, since  Cloudflare has decided to support (and perhaps control) it).
